description: A widespread freshwater fish found across northern and central Australia, known for forming large schools.
A colorful species native to the Murray-Darling Basin, commonly found in slow-moving or still waters.
A group of small, bottom-dwelling freshwater fish common in Australian rivers and streams.
A native Australian freshwater fish popular with anglers, known for its golden hue and strong fighting ability.
Small, schooling fish that inhabit a variety of freshwater and estuarine environments in Australia.
The largest native freshwater fish in Australia, a top predator and a culturally significant species.
A medium-sized native fish that was once abundant in the Murray-Darling system, now subject to conservation efforts.
A hardy and adaptable fish, widely distributed throughout inland Australia.
A bottom-dwelling native catfish with distinctive barbels, valued both ecologically and recreationally.
Small, slender-bodied fish that form schools in a variety of habitats, important prey for larger fish.
An invasive species introduced to control mosquitoes, now widespread and harmful to native fauna.
An introduced ornamental species often found in the wild, known to impact native ecosystems.
A large, invasive fish species that causes significant damage to freshwater habitats in Australia.
A small, attractive fish with blue eyes and yellow fins, found in coastal streams and estuaries.
A translucent, small-bodied species found in slow-moving or still waters across eastern Australia.
A livebearing fish introduced from South America, often found in urban streams.
A small, migratory fish known for its importance to the whitebait fishery.
A tiny goby species found in estuaries and freshwater streams, often hiding in vegetation.
A striking native gudgeon with purple markings, now rare in many parts of its former range.
One of the most widespread and adaptable native fish in Australia, tolerating a range of conditions.
A small gudgeon with a bright red tail, common in slow-flowing waters and billabongs.
A native catfish with an elongated body and venomous spines, found across northern Australia.
A highly adaptable and vividly colored species found in a wide range of eastern Australian waters.
A highly invasive cichlid species introduced for aquaculture, now threatening native ecosystems.

A predatory freshwater fish native to Europe and northern Asia, known for its green body with dark vertical stripes and red-orange fins. Common in lakes and slow rivers, it preys on smaller fish and invertebrates.

A rare and endangered Australian freshwater fish closely related to the Murray Cod. Recognized by its bluish-grey body and distinctive blotched pattern, it inhabits fast-flowing upland rivers and requires conservation efforts to support recovery.

An elongated, bottom-dwelling fish native to East Asia but introduced in parts of Australia. It is known for its ability to survive in low-oxygen environments and its sensitivity to changes in barometric pressure, which gives it the nickname 'weatherloach'.
A small, native Australian freshwater fish with a broad, flattened head, commonly found in slow-moving rivers and streams. It is an ambush predator that feeds on insects and small crustaceans.
A small, cryptic freshwater fish native to eastern Australia, distinguished by its broad head and compact size. Typically inhabits weedy or still waters and preys on tiny aquatic invertebrates.
A small, schooling fish found in northern and eastern Australia, known for its adaptability to a wide range of salinities and its role in the aquatic food web as prey for larger species.
A solitary, nocturnal freshwater fish native to southeastern Australia, known for its mottled coloration and preference for cool, clear, fast-flowing streams with ample cover.
A small, slender-bodied freshwater fish native to southeastern Australia, typically found in slow-flowing streams, wetlands, and floodplains with dense vegetation.
A genus of brightly colored freshwater fish commonly found across northern and eastern Australia. Known for their shimmering scales and peaceful schooling behavior in rivers, creeks, and billabongs.
